thread.title: Cocaine users are more likely to have sexually transmitted diseases - for this reason
thread.title_full: Cocaine users are more likely to have sexually transmitted diseases - for this reason

author: Adam Boult
title: Cocaine users are more likely to have sexually transmitted diseases - for this reason

organizations.name: johns hopkins university school of medicine

text:
P eople who regularly use cocaine are more likely to have sexually transmitted diseases than non-users.
According to a new study by researchers at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, this may in part be due to a "sexual-impatience" brought on by the drug which increases the likelihood that users will not bother to use condoms.
"Our study affirms and may help explain why people who regularly use cocaine are more willing to partake in risky sex when under the influence of cocaine, and underscores why public health officials and physicians should be ensuring that cocaine users are supplied with condoms to prevent the spread of sexually transmitted disease," said researcher Matthew Johnson.
Looking at 12 volunteers - all self-identified cocaine users - researchers asked them to look at 60 photographs of people and select they would be willing to have casual sex with, and those they thought were least likely to have an STI.
Researchers then asked the participants to rate their likelihood of using a condom if one was immediately available, and to indictate how long they would be willing to wait to get a condom before having sex.
The longer a participant on cocaine had to wait to use a condom, researchers found, the more willing they would be to have sex without one
"The bottom line is that cocaine appears to increase sexual desire, and even though users who are on cocaine report being likely to use a condom if they had one in a risky sex situation, if a condom isn't available, cocaine makes people less willing to postpone sex to get a condom," said Johnson. "They become more impatient when it comes to waiting for sex."
A 2016 previous study looking at decision-making during alcohol found similar results, said Johnson. Alcohol, like cocaine, would make people less likely to wait for a condom - but unlike cocaine, it not strongly increase sexual arousal.
